text: Mia 25 years we come this is neo
MacFarquhar of the New York Times life
has been hard for the three million
Darfur E's who fled their homes to live

in a shantytown that was supposed to be
temporary but is beginning to feel
permanent there is a market in the
middle of some camps and water pumps
have been built on solid concrete bases
schooling is limited
usually only through the eighth grade
there are whole generations of children
being born in the camps growing up in
the camps with never anything but camp
life so there's all sorts of dangers of
course is also the danger of
politicization in camps which make them
more difficult to manage
Davian tell America many men like Adam
Haroon Ahmed arrived as teenagers but

Arabic for young men we hit full freedom
in the village for everybody there's no

middle as it
a rising political force in the camps
the young men are increasingly angry and
outspoken about their uncertain fate and
the insecurity that troubles their lives
that's what I mean
they also strain against the traditional
tribal leaders or sheiks UN officials
say the Shabaab take justice into their
own hands
organizing vigilante squads to punish
anyone who speaks of compromise with the
Sudanese government
Sudan's President Omar al-bashir draws
especially strong criticism with many
here hoping for further progress on the
possible genocide and war crimes
indictment from the International
Criminal Court i arrest amar and we can
go that will solve the case and we can
go try him don't let him stay in power
we need another president when President

back
despite troubles in the camps Mohamed
and many others like him have no
interest in returning to the ordinary

living from the harsh terrain they all
say that their main concern now is
getting an education especially English
I don't want to be a farmer before when
